{{Infobox football tournament season | title = Football League Cup | year = 2009â10 | other_titles = Carling Cup, League Cup | image = Carling Cup logo 2009-10.jpg | imagesize = | caption = The logo of the 2009â10 League Cup | country = {{ENG}} & {{WAL}} | num_teams = 92 | champions = [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] | runner-up = [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]] | matches = 93 | goals = 304 | top goal scorer = [[Carlos TÃ©vez]] (6 goals) | player = | prevseason = [[2008â09 Football League Cup|2008â09]] | nextseason = [[2010â11 Football League Cup|2010â11]] }} The '''2009â10 Football League Cup''', known as the ''Carling Cup'' due to the competition's sponsorship by lager brand [[Carling]], was the 50th season of the [[Football League Cup]], a knock-out competition for [[England]]'s top 92 [[association football|football]] clubs.{{cite news |title=2009/10 Carling Cup Dates Revealed |url=http://www.football-league.co.uk/page/News/CarlingCupNews/0,,10794~1597362,00.html |publisher=The Football League |date=20 March 2009 |accessdate=26 May 2009 }} [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] successfully defended their Football League Cup title after defeating [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]] by 2–1 in the final at [[Wembley Stadium]] on 28 February 2010. Each season, the League Cup winners â like the winners of the FA Cup â are granted a place in the [[UEFA Europa League]] for the following season. However, in cases where a team has already gained a place in European competition via their league position or progress in other cup competitions, their place in the Europa League is deferred to the next-placed league side. In this season, since Manchester United and FA Cup winners [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] qualified for the [[UEFA Champions League]] via the Premier League, Aston Villa and [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] qualified for the Europa League as the sixth- and seventh-placed sides in the league. ==First Round== The draw for the First Round took place on 16 June 2009, with matches played two months later in the week beginning 10 August 2009.{{cite news |title=2009/10 Carling Cup Key Dates |url=http://www.football-league.co.uk/page/KeyDates/0,,10794~1357319,00.html |publisher=The Football League |date=1 August 2008 |accessdate=26 May 2009 }}{{cite news |title=Clubs discover Carling Cup fate |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/league_cup/8102230.stm |work=BBC Sport |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |date=16 June 2009 |accessdate=16 June 2009 }} [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] and [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]] received a first round bye as the highest ranked [[The Football League 2009â10|Football League]] teams from the previous season's league placings.{{cite news |title=North East sides receive Cup bye |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/league_cup/8081683.stm |work=BBC Sport |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |date=3 June 2009 |accessdate=3 June 2009 }} The other 70 of the 72 [[The Football League 2009â10|Football League]] clubs competed in the First Round, divided into North and South sections. Each section was divided equally into a pot of seeded clubs and a pot of unseeded clubs. Clubs' rankings depend upon their finishing position in the [[2008â09 in English football|2008â09 season]]. {{col-begin}} {{col-2}} {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center" |- |+ North |- 1 Score after 90 minutes ==Second Round== The 13 [[2009â10 Premier League|Premier League]] teams not involved in European competitions entered at this stage, along with the winners from the First Round plus [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] and [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]], who received a First Round bye. From the Second Round onwards, the teams are no longer split geographically. The draw for the Second Round took place on 12 August 2009, after the First Round games had been completed,{{cite news |title=Carling Cup second-round draw |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/league_cup/8198604.stm |work=BBC Sport |publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation |date=12 August 2009 |accessdate=12 August 2009 }} and the matches were Round== The draw for the Fourth Round took place after the Third Round games had been played, on 26 September 2009, and the matches were played on the week beginning on 26 October 2009. {{penmiss|saved}} [[GaÃ«l Kakuta|Kakuta]] }} ==Semi-finals== The semi-final draw took place on 2 December 2009, after the completion of the first three Fifth Round matches. The first leg matches were to be played the week commencing 4 January 2010, but adverse weather conditions including severe snow and ice in [[North West England]] caused the games to be rearranged. ===First leg=== {{footballbox |date=14 January 2010 |time=20:00 |team1=[[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]] |score=0 – 1 |report=[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/league_cup/8451967.stm Report] |team2=[[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]] |goals1= |goals2=[[James Milner|Milner]] {{goal|23}} |stadium=[[Ewood Park]], [[Blackburn]] |attendance=18,595 |referee=[[Mark Clattenburg]] ([[Durham County Football Association|County Durham]]) }} ---- {{footballbox |date=19 January 2010 |time=20:00 |team1=[[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] |score=2 – 1 |report=[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/league_cup/8465407.stm Report] |team2=[[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] |goals1=[[Carlos TÃ©vez|TÃ©vez]] {{goal|42|pen.|65}} |goals2=[[Ryan Giggs|Giggs]] {{goal|17}} |stadium=[[City of Manchester Stadium]], [[Manchester]] |attendance=46,067 |referee=[[Mike Dean (referee)|Mike Dean]] ([[Cheshire County Football Association|Cheshire]]) }} ===Second leg=== {{footballbox |date=20 January 2010 |time = 19:45 |team1=[[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]] |score=6 – 4 |report=[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/league_cup/8466159.stm Report] |team2=[[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]] |goals1=[[Stephen Warnock|Warnock]] {{goal|30}}

[[Brett Emerton|Emerton]] {{goal|84}} |stadium=[[Villa Park]], [[Birmingham]] |attendance=40,406 |referee=[[Martin Atkinson]] ([[West Riding County Football Association|West Yorkshire]]) }} ''Aston Villa won 7–4 on aggregate.'' ---- {{footballbox |date=27 January 2010 |time=20:00 |team1=[[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] |score=3 – 1 |report=[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/league_cup/8473135.stm Report] |team2=[[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] |goals1=[[Paul Scholes|Scholes]] {{goal|52}}

[[Wayne Rooney|Rooney]] {{goal|74}} |stadium=[[Wembley Stadium]], [[London]] |attendance=88,596 |referee=[[Phil Dowd]] ([[Staffordshire Football Association|Staffordshire]]) }} ==Prize money== The prize money is awarded by the Football League. The winners of the League Cup won Â£100,000 and the runners-up won Â£50,000. The losing semi-finalists each took home Â£25,000.{{cite web |url=http://www.carling.com/contactus/footballQ.html |title=Football Queries |publisher=Carling.com |accessdate=24 September 2009 }} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.carlingcup.co.uk Official Carling Cup website] * [http://www.football-league.co.uk/page/CarlingCup/0,,10794,00.html Carling Cup News] at football-league.co.uk * [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/league_cup/default.stm Carling Cup] at bbc.co.uk {{Football League Cup seasons}} {{2009â10 in English football}} {{2009â10 in European Football (UEFA)}} [[Category:Football League Cup seasons|2009-10]] [[Category:2009â10 Football League|League Cup]] [[Category:2009â10 in English football|League Cup]] [[Category:2009â10 domestic association football cups|Football League Cup]] {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2010}} [[bg:ÐÑÐ¿Ð° Ð½Ð° ÑÑÑÐ±Ð¾Ð»Ð½Ð°ÑÐ° Ð»Ð¸Ð³Ð° 2009/10]] [[es:Copa de la Liga de Inglaterra 2009-10]] [[fr:Coupe de la Ligue anglaise de football 2009-2010]] [[it:Football League Cup 2009-2010]] [[hu:2009â2010-es angol labdarÃºgÃ³-ligakupa]] [[nl:Football League Cup 2009-10]] [[no:Den engelske ligacupen 2009â2010]] [[ru:ÐÑÐ±Ð¾Ðº Ð¤ÑÑÐ±Ð¾Ð»ÑÐ½Ð¾Ð¹ Ð»Ð¸Ð³Ð¸ 2009/2010]] [[zh:2009è³2010å¹´è±æ ¼è­è¯è³½ç]]
